page_analysis.text_content:
Gross vs. net lot area

Gross lot area is the size of the lot—from lot line to lot line.
Development potential is based on the net lot area and
while gross and net lot area are the same for most lots in
Palo Alto, there are some lots for which portions must be
excluded from the gross lot area to establish the net lot area.

Areas excluded from the gross lot size are:
• Street right-of-way (Area A of Fig 1 on this page)
• “Pole” portion of a flag lot (Area B of Fig 2 on this page)
• Creek channel (Area C of Fig 3 on this page)

Fig 1 Gross lot area exclusions: street easements

Lot with
boundaries
that extend
into the
public ROW

The portion of the lot within the
public ROW must be subtracted
from the gross lot area.

Note: In some areas of Palo Alto, like
Barron Park, it is not unusual for the
lot to extend to the middle of the
street. However
purposes, the lot is defined by the
edge of the public street easement or
public right-of-way (ROW).
Dimensions for the public ROW are
available at the Development Center

Public ROW

visual_elements.description: Figure 2: Gross lot area exclusions: flag-lot “poles”. This diagram illustrates two flag lots. The left lot is labeled 'Flag lot accessed via private easement' and shows a rectangular lot with a dashed line indicating a private easement leading to it. The right lot is labeled 'Flag lot with "pole"' and shows a rectangular lot connected to a 'Street' by a narrow strip of land, labeled 'B' and shaded grey, representing the 'pole' portion. An arrow points from 'B' to text explaining that the 'pole' portion must be subtracted from the gross lot size. Another note clarifies that private access easements are NOT subtracted.

Figure 1: Gross lot area exclusions: street easements. This diagram shows a street (labeled 'Public ROW') with two cars on it, indicating a roadway. A lot boundary extends into this public ROW. The area within the public ROW, labeled 'A' and shaded grey, is indicated as the portion to be subtracted from the gross lot area. A note explains that in some areas, lots extend to the middle of the street, but for planning purposes, the lot is defined by the edge of the public street easement or ROW.

Figure 3: Gross lot area exclusions: creek easements. This diagram depicts a lot adjacent to a creek. The creek area, labeled 'C' and shaded grey, is shown with wavy lines representing water and is within a 'Creek easement'. An arrow points from 'C' to text explaining that this portion must be subtracted from the gross lot size. A 'Top of bank' line is also indicated. A note clarifies that the channel or area to be subtracted is defined by the Santa Clara Valley Water District's easement or the top-of-bank, and may require a surveyor.
Key for symbols used in the diagrams. It includes symbols for Curb, Sidewalk, Lot lines, Creek, and Area that must be subtracted from gross lot area.

subheadings: Areas excluded from the gross lot size are:
sections: Fig 1 Gross lot area exclusions: street easements
Fig 2 Gross lot area exclusions: flag-lot “poles”
Fig 3 Gross lot area exclusions : creek easements

additional_notes: Page number '3' is present at the bottom right corner.

The text ': Private access easements >ts that provide access to lots are NOT subtracted the lot on which they occur.' in Fig 2 appears slightly misaligned or truncated, possibly due to photocopying or original document formatting.

The text 'However purposes, the lot is defined by the edge of the public street easement or public right-of-way (ROW).' in the note for Fig 1 seems to have a missing word or phrase between 'However' and 'purposes'.
